title: Local Labor Market Effects of Mergers and Acquisitions in Developing Countries: Evidence from Brazil. (arXiv:2306.08797v1 [econ.GN])
abstract: I use matched employer-employee records merged with corporate tax information from 2003 to 2017 to estimate labor market-wide effects of mergers and acquisitions in Brazil. Labor markets are defined by pairs of commuting zone and industry sector. In the following year of a merger, market size falls by 10.8%. The employment adjustment is concentrated in merging firms. For the firms not involved in M&As, I estimate a 1.07% decline in workers earnings and a positive, although not significant, increase in their size. Most mergers have a predicted impact of zero points in concentration, measured by the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI). I spillover firms, earnings decline similarly for mergers with high and low predicted changes in HHI. Contrary to the recent literature on market concentration in developed economies, I find no evidence of oligopsonistic behavior in Brazilian labor markets.

translated_title: 发展中国家中并购对本地劳动市场的影响：以巴西为例
translated_abstract: 本文利用2003年至2017年期间匹配的雇主-员工记录和企业税务信息，估计了巴西并购对整个劳动市场的影响。将劳动市场定义为通勤区和行业部门的组合。并购的下一年，市场规模下降了10.8%。雇佣调整集中在合并企业中。对于未涉及并购的企业，我估计工人收入下降了1.07％，但规模呈正增长趋势，尽管没有显著增长。大多数并购对于市场占有度的变化没有预测影响，以哈夫曼-赫希曼指数（HHI）为衡量标准。对于附带效应的企业来说，与HHI变化显著性相比，收入下降情况相似。与发达经济体市场占有度最近的文献相反，在巴西劳动市场没有寡头垄断行为的证据。
tldr: 本研究针对巴西，利用2003年至2017年期间的雇主-员工记录和企业税务信息研究了并购对劳动市场的影响。研究发现，并购会导致市场规模下降，雇佣调整集中在合并企业中，而不涉及并购的企业工人收入下降，规模增长。大多数并购对于市场占有度的变化没有预测影响。在巴西劳动市场没有发现寡头垄断行为的证据。
en_tdlr: This study examines the effects of mergers and acquisitions on the labor market in Brazil using matched employer-employee records and corporate tax information from 2003 to 2017. The study found that mergers lead to a decrease in market size, with employment adjustment focused on the merging firms. Non-merging firms experience a decline in worker earnings and a positive but insignificant increase in size. Most mergers have no predicted impact on market concentration, and no evidence of oligopsonistic behavior was found in the Brazilian labor market.
